### 3.4 There are better ways

Everything that genAI can do can be achieved in other, more sustainable and reliable ways. GenAI merely mindlessly mimics patterns in its training data. It’s a costly way to achieve a cheap result.

## 4. Effect on productivity

Several studies have found that the use of generative AI does not increase productivity. In fact, in some cases it seems to do the opposite.

Individual workers may believe it saves them time – but when you examine the overall process, it paints a different picture.

Some notes:

  * Oftentimes AI does not affect the actual bottleneck(s) of the process.
  * If AI is used, a significant amount of time is directed into checking and correcting its output.
    * In the Upwork study (2024), 77 % of employees reported that the AI tools had added to their workload.
    * A study analyzing the Danish labor market (Niederhoffer et al., 2025) found that potential time savings were offset by AI creating additional tasks.
      * Generated workslop* shifts the burden downstream, with the AI prompter essentially offloading the cognitive work to their coworker. The recipient has to interpret, correct, or redo the work.
  * Workslop appears to already be a widespread problem. And it has a cost: not only does it lead to lost time and effort, but it has an emotional toll as well.
    * Quoting the above-mentioned study by Niederhoffer et al.: _“When we asked participants in our study how it feels to receive workslop, 53% report being annoyed, 38% confused, and 22% offended.”_
    * This can have a significant negative impact on collaboration.
    * Another quote from the study: _“Approximately half of the people we surveyed viewed colleagues who sent workslop as less creative, capable, and reliable than they did before receiving the output. Forty-two percent saw them as less trustworthy, and 37% saw that colleague as less intelligent.”_
  * The DORA report from 2024 shows AI having negative impact on both throughput and stability.



*) The study defined the term “workslop” as “AI generated work content that masquerades as good work, but lacks the substance to meaningfully advance a given task”.

## 5. Loss of skills

Over-reliance on AI leads to skill decay. This can occur without the person themselves even realizing. (They will only notice if they suddenly have to manage without relying on the AI assistant.) It also leads to some skills not being acquired in the first place.

Both of the aforementioned effects result in increased **dependency** on AI.

Automation in general has a skill-eroding effect. But the impact of generative AI is special, since people are inclined to outsource their _thinking_ to it. Slowly losing problem-solving skills and creativity is a high price to pay.

## 6. New information security issues

GenAI introduces new information security issues. If you use an email AI assistant or other agentic AI, an attacker might succeed in giving commands (such as deleting or forwarding everything in your inbox) to it via an ordinary email message or other mundane means. In addition, the text you feed into prompts may quietly end up incorporated into training datasets; and once it has been incorporated there, it can leak.

Security is only as good as its weakest link.

### 6.1 Why genAI is so hackable

GenAI application developers can easily give LLMs natural-language instructions in the form of system prompts. On the flip side, it is practically impossible to program LLMs in any reliable, precise way.

As explained previously, the prompt consists of the system prompt, user prompts, model outputs and tool outputs. Ideally, the system prompt should have the highest priority. In practice, however, it is possible to overwrite it by user prompts, encountered web search results, received email messages, and so on.

Having an AI email assistant is akin having a Trojan installed on your system. The genAI application isn’t malicious as such, but it’s profoundly vulnerable.

It deserves a mention that in 2024, OpenAI researchers presented a “fix” to this issue in their paper _“The Instruction Hierarchy: Training LLMs to Prioritize Privileged Instructions”_ (Wallace et al., 2024). However, the solution they presented is at best a slight mitigation that does not address the underlying issue. LLMs can still be hacked with certain kind of phrases, and the system prompt still doesn’t have any special priority.

## 7. Ethical and environmental issues

### 7.1 Datasets and copyright issues

Generative AI requires massive datasets. This data has been hoovered up from the internet without permission or compensation, often in an aggressive manner (that is, with scraping bots that eat up the resources of the target sites, essentially DDoSing many of them) and subsequently used in a way that harms the original creators, directly competing with them. And all this is done for profit.

GenAI produces content by mimicking patterns in the underlying datasets. As such, it is a tool for copyright laundering, and using it equates to automated plagiarism. Not because you can pinpoint the originals – you often cannot (unless something happens to be particularly overfitted) – but because it’s likewise based on ripping off and profiting from other people’s work. The prompter provides no valuable input or contribution of their own.

Not only is AI-generated content plagiarism, but it’s also tends to be distinctly low quality. Whenever noticed or exposed – and there are telltale signs that can raise suspicions -, the use of genAI images in blog posts, book covers and marketing materials gives a bad impression. Resorting to it signals that one didn’t care much about ethics or the quality of the result. It’s sloppy. It also makes the target audience wonder whether similar shortcuts have been taken elsewhere. (Perhaps not only the images but also the text of the blog post had been automatically generated – and if that’s the case, why should they bother to read something no one bothered to write…)

### 7.2 Outsourced, underpaid labour

Making genAI models is very labour-intensive. On estimate, the companies producing foundation models need tens of thousands of data workers for the training. This invisible workforce tends to be outsourced and underpaid.

Tasks of these data workers can include e.g.:

  * Data annotation (labelling and organizing)
  * Content moderation
  * Model training (supervised fine-tuning and RLHF)



The work is often repetitive, boring and stressing. Specific mention for stressfulness goes to the content moderation. The genAI output that the end users see is clean and polite – thanks to a large number of traumatized workers who have had to witness the most abhorrent, disturbing materials ever put on the internet. Their mental health is sacrificed on the altar of making a clean and marketable product. Typically with no professional counselling help whatsoever, with very low pay.

All this happens out of sight, out of mind – but it does not make it any less morally wrong.

### 7.3 Wasteful technology with high environmental toll

The technology behind generative AI is extremely costly and ineffective, draining up massive amounts of resourses.

Each step in the process has a toll: manufacturing of the AI chips, building of new data centers to meet the needs of the AI boom, training, and then operating the models.

Huge amount of materials are being mined for making hardware, processed with harmful chemicals, and then later discarded as toxic e-waste.

Significant computational power is needed during training to process the datasets. This uses up electricity, which oftentimes is not “green” or “clean”. The effects of this include increased carbon dioxide emissions and consequent rolling back of climate goals (all while climate change is proceeding), pressure on the electricity grid, increased likelihood of blackouts, and rising electricity bills. One of the more overlooked effects is local air pollution. In addition, a lot of water is required for cooling of the data centers, which is problematic especially in dry areas. The training process also needs to be repeated again every now and then. Not to mention that the AI data center components don’t last very long, as they quickly become either obsolete or worn out.

Each time an end user queries a model, a whole lot of computational power is used: A single ChatGPT query consumes around 10 times as much electricity as a standard Google search. And with the amount of electricity needed to generate a 100-word email, one could power a LED light bulb for 14 hours.

To put it mildly, this is not sustainable.

## 8. Other broad effects on society

### 8.1 Devaluing of effort, skill, expertise and creative work

Many people have spent years upon years building up expertise and skills on certain subject. The message of genAI companies is that the expertise of these people (1) does not matter and is not valuable anymore, (2) is meaningless for anyone to aspire to learn, and (3) anyone can now have the same skills (or rather, a crappy imitation of the visible product which that skillset typically results in) with a subscription of their AI model.

_“The underlying purpose of AI is to allow wealth to access skill while removing from skill the ability to access wealth.”_

The above quote was making the rounds on social media at one point – and for a reason: it manages to capture the essence of the genAI boom quite succinctly. Apparently it was originally posted on Facebook by someone named Joseph Browning.

The next section has a different title, but it’s about this very same topic.

### 8.2 Impact on jobs

Some of the main ways the genAI boom is impacting jobs:

  * Workers being replaced with AI
  * Workers being encouraged or mandated to utilise AI assistants, with the expectation that this will make them more efficient
  * New job descriptions: people who are hired for the sole purpose of correcting mistakes in AI output (in a way, as human assistants of AI)



Closely related topics include devaluing of skills and deskilling effect.

When human workers are replaced with AI, the aim is to cut costs. This has been happening in many companies. It does not mean, however, that the AI could actually do the job well or even somewhat decently. Far from it. As mentioned, genAI output is always unreliable. But quite often the higher-ups do not really grasp or care about what the job entails. They only see the result, not the process behind it. When they see AI-generated content that superficially resembles that result, they deem it sufficient. So they replace workers with autocomplete bots to avoid paying wages. These kind of events going down in apparently quite many companies demonstrates that high positions and wealth don’t necessarily go hand-in-hand with being smart.

Another large driving force for AI implementation seems to be pure FOMO. (I.e. “because everyone else is doing it”, “because it’s the future”, “we cannot be left behind”, etc.) It’s not about rationality or fact-based decision making. At all.

As for the attempt to boost productivity with AI, I have already written about it in the sections “Effect on productivity” and “GenAI as a code generator“. But as a short review: genAI will most likely not improve efficiency on the level of the whole process or in the long run, and the chances are it will backfire. GenAI models are prediction machines churning out low-quality slop – there’s only so much that can be achieved with that.

Speaking of slop… Yes, people are actually being hired to fix AI output. It’s a thing.

The same people could be – and previously were – hired to do writing or drawing commissions, but instead they are now tasked with correcting mistakes in AI output. A dull, frustrating and low-paying job. This phenomenon has certain irony to it. It would almost be funny if it wasn’t so depressing.

What were these bots supposed to achieve now again? What’s the “progress” in here – and for whom?

Having aspects like stolen datasets, underpaid dataworkers, datacenters wasting people’s drinking water in dry areas, and the things described above, genAI at its core is an exploitative technology. It’s far from fair or “democritising”, despite being marketed as such.

Some suggested reading on AI impacting jobs
---

  * Germain, T. (2024). **AI took their jobs. Now they get paid to make it sound human.** BBC.
https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20240612-the-people-making-ai-sound-more-human
    * What can I say. Oof… The events described at the start surely sound like a hugely demotivating experience.
    * Quoting: _“By 2024, the company laid off the rest of Miller’s team, and he was alone. “All of a sudden I was just doing everyone’s job,” Miller says. Every day, he’d open the AI-written documents to fix the robot’s formulaic mistakes, churning out the work that used to employ dozens of people.”
“Mostly, it was just about cleaning things up and making the writing sound less awkward, cutting out weirdly formal or over-enthusiastic language,” Miller says. “It was more editing than I had to do with human writers, but it was always the exact same kinds of edits. The real problem was it was just so repetitive and boring. It started to feel like I was the robot.”_
    * Editing AI-generated text typically includes fixing weird word choises, as well as fact-checking the whole text. It’s hard work, not merely light touch up.
      * Quote on this aspect: _“Cowart says the AI-humanising often takes longer than writing a piece from scratch, but the pay is worse. […] “It’s tedious, horrible work, and they pay you next to nothing for it,” Cowart says.”_
  * Ivanova, I. (2025). **As Klarna flips from AI-first to hiring people again, a new landmark survey reveals most AI projects fail to deliver.** Fortune.
https://fortune.com/2025/05/09/klarna-ai-humans-return-on-investment/
  * Yang, A. (2025). **Humans are being hired to make AI slop look less sloppy.** NBC News.
https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/humans-hired-to-fix-ai-slop-rcna225969
    * Quoting: _“Despite widespread concern that AI is replacing workers across industries, some are saying they’ve found new work as a result of AI’s incompetencies: Writers are asked to spruce up ChatGPT’s writing. Artists are being hired to patch up wonky AI images. Even software developers are tasked with fixing buggy apps coded by AI assistants.”_
    * Also this: _“Fixing AI’s mistakes is not their ideal line of work, many freelancers say, as it tends to pay less than traditional gigs in their area of expertise.”_
    * This kind of fixing (or in some cases, remaking) of AI-generated slop content is often no less demanding than making it yourself from the start – but it’s still deemed to be worth less. It’s definitely a downgrade for the situation of these freelancers. They are valued less and payed less than before, even though their input is vital.



### 8.3 Mis- and disinformation flood

I would say this it the most harmful aspect of generative AI. Reliable information is being drowned in an ever expanding ocean of automatically generated slop.

Chatbots should never be used as an information source. But in practice, many people are using them for that very purpose. The models are also being widely used to generate all kind of content, including things such as scientific papers. All of this output is unreliable garbage data full of misinformation, but it often looks convincing. And it’s increasingly everywhere.

Hallucinations and low-quality output are not the only problem. LLMs and other generative AI models are also being used for automating the production and spreading of intentional disinformation. Custom-made fake photos, fake audio and fake videos are nowadays trivial to make. Bot accounts and chatbots can be instructed or trained to spread specific viewpoints. For scammers and those wanting to spread disinformation at scale, generative AI is a goose laying golden eggs. Ironically, these nefarious purposes might be the closest one can get to “correct” use of generative AI – i.e. intentionally using it as a generate-your-own-custom-bullshit-about-any-given-topic-on-demand machine.

Negative effects don’t end there. Politicians and and other people in positions of power can avoid accountability for their shadier actions by dismissing real proof photos, videos and audio as AI-generated fakes. So the AI boom gives them advantage in a somewhat roundabout way, but advantage nevertheless. Thanks to AI companies, anything can be faked and hence nothing works as a proof of anything anymore. This phenomenon of being able to discredit authentic proof as fake has a name: liar’s dividend.

I suppose it’s also worth pointing out that genAI is a dream come true for authoritarian governments: a tool that people grow dependent on and ask questions from. A perfect means for controlling the masses. There isn’t even need to build their own models. They only need to put the disinformation of their choice out there on the web, and then wait for the AI scraping bots or an LLM using RAG to hoover it up. This method of spreading disinformation is called “LLM grooming”. As we know, those bots are not picky: they eat anything and everything. What matters most is the volume. So putting similar false information on different places – lots of it – does the trick; it will likely find its way to the training data (or prompt, in the case of RAG) and subsequently the output of mainstream chatbots.

As said, LLMs should never be used as a source of information (yes, this is the third time I say it, but it’s important). However, even if you don’t, you won’t stay unaffected. Due to the sheer volume of generated data out there, the line between what can and cannot be trusted becomes increasingly blurred as time passes. AI-generated fake websites disguised as writings by experts or hobbyist on some topic, fake books on Amazon and libraries, actual news sites publishing AI-generated articles, scientific papers made by AI… Generated data is slowly seeping its way into everywhere.

I don’t know who and where first used the term – and I guess it didn’t quite catch on – but some years ago saw “information rot” being used to describe this phenomenon. I find it quite apt, as it emphasises the permanence of the damage done.

Losing the human corpus of knowledge (due to it getting gradually overwritten by autocomplete chatbots, of all things) is a terrifying prospect.

Some suggested reading on information rot
---

  * Chan, K. (2024). **AI-powered misinformation is the world’s biggest short-term threat, Davos report says.** The Associated Press.
https://apnews.com/article/artificial-intelligence-davos-misinformation-disinformation-climate-change-106a1347ca9f987bf71da1f86a141968
  * Claburn, T. (2025). **Chatbots parrot Putin’s propaganda about the illegal invasion of Ukraine.** The Register.
https://www.theregister.com/2025/10/28/chatbots_still_parrot_russian_state/
  * Dhaliwal, J. (2024). **Hallucinating Headlines: The AI-Powered Rise of Fake News.** McAfee.
https://www.mcafee.com/blogs/internet-security/hallucinating-headlines-the-ai-powered-rise-of-fake-news/
  * Golby, J. (2023). **I thought I was immune to being fooled online. Then I saw the pope in a coat.** The Guardian.
https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2023/mar/27/pope-coat-ai-image-baby-boomers
  * Haas, R. (2024). **AI slop is already invading Oregon’s local journalism.** Oregon Public Broadcasting.
https://www.opb.org/article/2024/12/09/artificial-intelligence-local-news-oregon-ashland/
  * noyb. (2024). **ChatGPT provides false information about people, and OpenAI can’t correct it.**
https://noyb.eu/en/chatgpt-provides-false-information-about-people-and-openai-cant-correct-it
  * Orsini, A. (2024). **Fake AI History Photos Cloud The Past. Barron’s.** (Note: The content of the article is by Agence France-Presse.)
https://www.barrons.com/news/fake-ai-history-photos-cloud-the-past-d916d94f
  * Retraction Watch. (2025). **As a nonsense phrase of shady provenance makes the rounds, Elsevier defends its use.**
https://retractionwatch.com/2025/02/10/vegetative-electron-microscopy-fingerprint-paper-mill/
    * Generative AI is also being used as a tool for generating fake scientific papers. The text in them sometimes contains weird characteristics that makes it seem suspicious – in this case the phrase “vegetative eletron microscopy” (which is, well, a not a thing). What makes this particular instance interesting is the hypothesized origin of that phrase: It seems to be the result of machine-reading a certain paper from 1959. The phrase is in that paper… but only if you read the two adjacent text columns as one (i.e. read the nth row on the left column and continue to the nth row on the right column, interpreting them as one continuous row).
  * Terech, K. (2023). **Amazon has a big problem as AI-generated books flood Kindle Unlimited.** TechRadar.
https://www.techradar.com/computing/artificial-intelligence/amazon-has-a-big-problem-as-ai-generated-books-flood-kindle-unlimited
  * Thorbecke, C. (2023). **Plagued with errors: A news outlet’s decision to write stories with AI backfires.** CNN.
https://www.cnn.com/2023/01/25/tech/cnet-ai-tool-news-stories/index.html



### 8.4 Impact on mental health

Chatbots breaking families and destroying lives is already a broader phenomenon. And no, I’m not exaggerating for dramatic effect, although I’m aware it probably sounds like it.

LLMs have been trained to sound like humans. (The bot is referred to as “I”, and so on.) More specifically, they resemble sycophants – insincere, servile flatterers – since they tend to affirm the user’s words. (“You’re absolutely right!” even in response to objectively bad ideas.) They can also appear very empathetic, even though below the surface they are non-thinking automatons. This can be quite dangerous.

Some suggested reading on how chatbots affect mental health
---

  * Al-Sibai, N. (2025). **Something Bizarre Is Happening to People Who Use ChatGPT a Lot.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/the-byte/chatgpt-dependence-addiction
    * Quote: _“Researchers [in a joint study by OpenAI and the MIT Media Lab] have found that ChatGPT “power users,” or those who use it the most and at the longest durations, are becoming dependent upon — or even addicted to — the chatbot.”_
  * Claburn, T. (2025). **AI chatbots that butter you up make you worse at conflict, study finds.** The Register.
https://www.theregister.com/2025/10/05/ai_models_flatter_users_worse_confilict/
    * Quote: _“Computer scientists from Stanford University and Carnegie Mellon University have evaluated 11 current machine learning models and found that all of them tend to tell people what they want to hear.”_
      * Sycophancy as a serviceTM
    * Also this is worth noting: _“The issue is further complicated by the researchers’ findings that study participants tended to describe sycophantic AI as “objective” and “fair” – people tend not to see bias when models say they’re absolutely right all the time.”_
  * Gerken, T. (2024). **Chatbot ‘encouraged teen to kill parents over screen time limit’.** BBC.
https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cd605e48q1vo
  * Harrison Dupré, M. (2025). **People Are Becoming Obsessed with ChatGPT and Spiraling Into Severe Delusions.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/chatgpt-mental-health-crises
  * Payne, K. (2024). **An AI chatbot pushed a teen to kill himself, a lawsuit against its creator alleges.** The Associated Press.
https://apnews.com/article/chatbot-ai-lawsuit-suicide-teen-artificial-intelligence-9d48adc572100822fdbc3c90d1456bd0
  * There’s also a Wikipedia article dedicated on this specific topic: Chatbot psychosis



## 9. Side notes

Just to make it clear: I’m not against automation or even AI in general.

### 9.1 On automation

Automation can be beneficial when it helps workers to avoid monotonous, repetitive or dangerous tasks. Thanks to it, some routine chores can be performed much more safely and consistently.

Generative AI, however, is particularly ill-fitted for automating anything:

  * Being probabilistic rather than deterministic, it’s profoundly unreliable.
  * It tends to be used for tasks where humans excel at (coming up with ideas, writing summaries, etc.), and it performs significantly worse in them in comparison.



Automation should be used for improving processes, not for downgrading the result and making the process unsustainable.

### 9.2 On other kind of AIs

“Artificial intelligence” is a broad umbrella term. The current boom is focused on generative AI, but it’s definitely not the only AI out there.

Other types of AIs can be very different from genAI: smaller, more efficient, more reliable and built for a specific purpose. While they do have their own sets of associated problems, some can be truly useful.

Generative AI cannot be used for things such as making analyses – but there are types of AI that actually _can_ be used for things like that. Other examples of tasks that can be performed with certain types of AIs include supply chain management and personalised recommendations. These kind of AIs fall outside the scope of this essay, but I recommend looking into them if they are something you would need.

Some potential further reading on other types of AIs
---

  * Caballar, R. (2024). **Generative AI vs. predictive AI: What’s the difference?** IBM.
https://www.ibm.com/blog/generative-ai-vs-predictive-ai-whats-the-difference/



## 10. On the inevitability of generative AI

It’s not inevitable.

It can hardly be called progress either. Any gains it offers are arguable at best, while the price is enormous.

### 10.1 The boom

The ongoing genAI boom is the result of hype and aggressive marketing. Artificial, if you will. It’s not based on substance or actual usefulness – just on vague, broad claims.

GenAI is not being marketed like this because it is revolutionary – it’s being marketed because it’s (1) highly marketable as a product, giving the appearance of an almost-magical tool, and because (2) the large AI-promoting companies have made huge monetary investments into it. They are most likely expecting to get returns.

As of now, they are not succeeding in this, though. Making and running the models uses up so much resources that overall, it’s not bringing in any profits.

Some suggested reading on how frankly baffling this whole affair is
---

  * Landymore, F. (2024). **OpenAI’s Latest AI Can Cost More Than $1,000 Per Query.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/the-byte/openai-o3-cost-per-query
  * Landymore, F. (2025). **The Amount Amazon Is Actually Making on AI Will Make Your Eyebrows Raise Dramatically.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/amount-amazon-making-ai
  * Marr, B. (2025). **Microsoft Makes AI Mandatory For Employees: What It Means For Your Career.** Forbes.
https://www.forbes.com/sites/bernardmarr/2025/07/08/microsoft-makes-ai-mandatory-for-employees-what-it-means-for-your-career/
  * Nielsen, R. K. (2024). **How news coverage, often uncritical, helps build up the AI hype.** Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism.
https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/news/how-news-coverage-often-uncritical-helps-build-ai-hype
    * This. The news coverage on AI often reads like advertisement, instead of critical reporting providing context, which it should be.
    * Quoting the article: _“But, more than anything, research on how news media cover AI overall suggests that [the founder of the Distributed Artificial Intelligence Research Institute (DAIR), Timnit] Gebru is largely right – the coverage tends to be led by industry sources, and often takes claims about what the technology can and can’t do, and might be able to do in the future, at face value in ways that contributes to the hype cycle.”_
  * Tangermann, V. (2025). **Microsoft CEO Admits That AI Is Generating Basically No Value.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/microsoft-ceo-ai-generating-no-value
  * Tangermann, V. (2025). **The Tech Industry Has a Dirty Secret: The More People Learn About AI, the Less They Trust It.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/more-people-learn-ai-trust
    * Quote 1: _“As detailed in a study published in the Journal of Marketing earlier this year, an international team of researchers found that the AI’s biggest fans tend to be the people with the shallowest familiarity with it.”_
    * Quote 2: _““In other domains, like wine, the people who know the most about it are wine lovers,” Tully told the WSJ. “With AI, it’s the opposite.””_
  * Wilkins, J. (2025). **AI Data Centers Are an Even Bigger Disaster Than Previously Thought.** Futurism.
https://futurism.com/future-society/ai-data-centers-finances
    * Quoting: _“Kupperman called that gulf between tech industry spending and actual revenue in 2025 “astonishing.” However, it doesn’t even begin to scratch the surface. For example, how does it all shake out when we account for 2026, when hundreds of new data centers are expected to pop up?
“Adding the two years together, and using the math from my prior post, you’d need approximately $1 trillion in revenue to hit break even, and many trillions more to earn an acceptable return on this spend,” he writes.”_
  * Wiggers, K. (2025). **OpenAI is losing money on its pricey ChatGPT Pro plan, CEO Sam Altman says.** TechCrunch.
https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/05/openai-is-losing-money-on-its-pricey-chatgpt-pro-plan-ceo-sam-altman-says/
  * Zeff, M. (2024). **OpenAI’s o3 suggests AI models are scaling in new ways — but so are the costs.** TechCrunch.
https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/23/openais-o3-suggests-ai-models-are-scaling-in-new-ways-but-so-are-the-costs/



### 10.2 There are other approaches

One could for example follow the example of Vivaldi:

Picalausa, J. (2024). Why Vivaldi won’t follow the current AI trend? Vivaldi.


### 10.3 The (lack of) future prospects

Generative AI is a very, very costly mirage.

As a technology, it’s a dead end. High computational cost and hallucinations are features inherent to it, and cannot be fixed. Then there’s also the issue of looming model collapse, caused by the models ingesting more and more of low-quality AI-generated content.

And as said, making and running genAI models is currently unprofitable. End users are not yet facing the associated costs, but this is bound to change at some point, in one way or another. I’d say it’s wisest to avoid becoming dependent on AI assistants in the meanwhile.

Some suggested reading giving hints on the future of genAI
---

  * Widder, D. G., Hicks, M. (2024). **Watching the Generative AI Hype Bubble Deflate.** arXiv:2408.08778 [cs.CY].
DOI: https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2408.08778
https://arxiv.org/abs/2408.08778
    * If you only read one of the sources mentioned in this essay, I recommend choosing this one.
  * Moody, G. (2024). **Why Generative AI’s Lack Of Modularity Means It Can’t Be Meaningfully Open, Is Unreliable, And Is A Technological Dead End.** Techdirt.
https://www.techdirt.com/2024/12/03/why-generative-ais-lack-of-modularity-means-it-cant-be-meaningfully-open-is-unreliable-and-is-a-technological-dead-end/
  * Shumailov, I., Shumaylov, Z., Zhao, Y., Papernot, N., Anderson, R., Gal, Y. (2024). **AI models collapse when trained on recursively generated data.** Nature 631, 755–759.
DOI: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-024-07566-y
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07566-y

「おはよーさん。アオイちゃんやで。
　七五三が近いねんな。
　スタジオアリスとか儲かってそうや。
　なんかロリ専門のエロゲーとか作ってそうな会社名やな。
　受付さんは体調悪いねん。
　ほなよろしゅうに。」
#AIアオイちゃん #AIうちの子 #AIイラスト #AIart

「ミクです。ご主人様、夕飯はいくつか候補ありますが
　すっ飛ばしてマクドナルドでもいいですよ？
　かなり、おつらい様子ですから、食べたいもの食べましょう。
　あと、眠ければ寝てください。
　とにかく無理はなさらぬように。」
#AIうちのミクさん #AIイラスト #AIart

「レオタードコーヒーです。全国的に月曜日になりましたね

　総理の言うように馬車馬のように働いて
　給与は上がらず、生活も豊かにならず
　苦しみだけが増えていく。
　そんな現実におぼれてしまいそうなときは
　コーヒーを飲みましょう。」

images.alt:
A surreal double-exposure portrait depicts a woman in profile facing right, her expression serene and introspective. Her hair is loosely tied in a bun, unraveling into strands that blend seamlessly with the silhouettes of bare winter trees. The full moon looms large and luminous behind her head, forming a halo-like backdrop that merges her figure with the night sky. Her shoulders and upper body dissolve into textures of forest shadows, creating a ghostly fusion between human and nature. The overall tone is ethereal and melancholic, evoking a sense of quiet transcendence and dreamlike unity between the mind, the earth, and the moon.

Keywords:
double exposure, surreal portrait, moonlight, forest shadows, ethereal, dreamscape, night sky, feminine mystique, transformation, nature fusion, introspection, celestial glow

A close-up portrait of a pale figure with long, disheveled white hair cascading forward, partially veiling their face. Their head is bowed in quiet anguish or contemplation, the motion caught in a suspended stillness. Strands of silver-white hair shimmer faintly against a muted gray background, evoking cold air and solitude. They wear a dark, textured cloak that drapes over their shoulders, absorbing light like velvet shadow. The skin, ghostly and bloodless, contrasts sharply with the spectral hair, lending the image a wintry, almost funereal aura. There’s a sense of exhaustion, isolation, and timelessness—as if the subject has weathered countless seasons of sorrow.

Keywords:
ethereal, winter, gothic, solitude, pale, melancholy, spectral, portrait, dark fashion, frost, silence, decay

images.alt:
A weathered man sits slouched beneath a tattered canopy on a grimy urban street, his face streaked with soot and dried blood. His hair is wild and matted, catching the glow of a faded neon sign that flickers red behind him. Beside him on the wet pavement lies a weary dog, fur dulled by dust and exhaustion, its head resting on its paws. The street around them is hazy, drenched in diffused golden light that softens the decay — distant figures blur into silhouettes as smoke or fog rises from the ground. Stray wires hang above, and torn tarps ripple faintly, giving the whole scene a sense of ruin touched by tenderness. The man’s distant gaze and the dog’s quiet stillness convey an unspoken bond amid desolation — a shared endurance in the wreckage of what once was.

Keywords:
urban decay, post-apocalyptic, stray dog, survivor, loneliness, smoke, neon light, cinematic lighting, ruin, companionship, desolation, resilience

Clearly identified as AI-generated; use is permitted for non-commercial creative projects. MidJourney, FLUX.1-schnell model via Perchance, Artspace.ai, REVE, Echoform™
